ETYMOLOGY: From Old French rascaille 'rabble, mob, scrapings', suggesting a person of low status or disreputable character. Adopted into English in the late 14th century, its meaning softened over time to include mischief.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A mischievous or naughty person, especially a child, often used in a fond or teasing way.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一个淘气或顽皮的人，尤指孩子，常用于亲切或开玩笑的语气。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: My youngest son is such a little rascal; he's always hiding my keys!
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我最小的儿子真是个小淘气包；他总是藏我的钥匙！

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A dishonest or unprincipled person; a scoundrel or villain. This usage is less common now or often softened.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一个不诚实或无原则的人；一个恶棍或流氓。此用法现在较少见或常被软化。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He called the politician a rascal for breaking his promises.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他称那个政客为无赖，因为他违背了诺言。

REGISTER: Informal, often used affectionately, especially when referring to children. Can also be used to describe a scoundrel, though this usage is less common or more jocular today.
